name: Muslim Community Center Chicago
mission: TEACHING AND RECITATION OF HOLY QURAN, FULL TIME SCHOOL, DAILY AND FRIDAY CONGRGATION, FUNERAL AND MARRIAGE SERVICES, AND CHILDREN AND ADULT EDUCATION.

evaluationSources: Greener Morton Grove Award (Morton Grove Economic Development Commission)

zakatClaimEvidence: The Muslim Community Center Chicago explicitly accepts zakat donations, as evidenced by their dedicated 'Rehab & Welfare/ Zakat Request' section, an 'Online Zakat Form', and the statement that their projects include 'overseeing zakat requests and distributions'. They also provide an email address for zakat inquiries: zakat@mccchicago.org. Furthermore, their website details 'What is Zakah?' and its importance in Islam. (Source: https://mccchicago.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/MCC-Voting-Results-2025.pdf)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: ibn_sabil (+5)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 25/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.
components.name: Theory of Change

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Muslim Community Center Incorporate shows moderate alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: The Muslim Community Center Chicago explicitly accepts zakat donations, as evidenced by their dedicated 'Rehab & Welfare/ Zakat Request' section, an 'Online Zakat Form', and the statement that their projects include 'overseeing zakat requests and distributions'. They also provide an email address for zakat inquiries: zakat@mccchicago.org. Furthermore, their website details 'What is Zakah?' and its importance in Islam. (Source: https://mccchicago.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/MCC-Voting-Results-2025.pdf)

all_citations.claim: The organization reported total revenue of $9,945,910, a program expense ratio of 93.4%, and provides religious and educational services.
Financial data indicates a fundraising efficiency of $0.03 per $1 raised and 23.6 months of working capital.
The organization maintains active community participation and governance through its voting results and program outcomes.
The organization offers various donation options and is recognized as Zakat-eligible.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its excellent financial health and efficiency metrics, balanced against a lack of detailed third-party impact data.
areas_for_improvement: Limited external data regarding specific long-term impact metrics and program outcomes
Opportunities to enhance transparency through third-party verification platforms

dimension_explanations.alignment: As a Zakat-eligible institution, the center shows a medium donor fit for those seeking to support traditional religious and cultural causes [1][4]. The organization maintains a steady track record of community engagement, evidenced by its active governance and voting processes [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates a capacity-building approach by maintaining a significant working capital of 23.6 months and a 93.4% program expense ratio, though specific cost-per-beneficiary data is currently unavailable [1][2]. Its impact is primarily driven through the maintenance of religious infrastructure and educational programs for children and adults [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Muslim Community Center Incorporate provides comprehensive religious, educational, and social services to the community with a strong commitment to financial efficiency.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 93.4%, ensuring the vast majority of funds directly support community services
Exceptional fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.03 to raise every $1
Strong liquidity position with 23.6 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: The Muslim Community Center Incorporate is a Zakat-eligible organization dedicated to the teaching and recitation of the Holy Quran, operating a full-time school and providing essential community services including funeral and marriage rites [1][3]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $9,945,910 while maintaining a high program expense ratio of 93.4% [1][2].

areas_for_improvement.detail: While program delivery is efficient, there is <cite id="13">no consistent publication of beneficiary counts</cite> or long-term outcome tracking.
The organization currently lacks a <cite id="14">documented theory of change</cite> with an explicit causal pathway for its various social services.

bbb_assessment.summary: BBB Wise Giving Alliance assessment not available for this organization.

risk_factors: <cite id="14">Absence of a formal theory of change</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concern is a <cite id="13">lack of standardized impact data</cite> and outcome metrics common in modern non-profits.

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data from 2023; voting results from 2025
confidence.notes: Strong financial data but significant gaps in impact reporting.

alignment.explanation: The organization is a strong fit for Muslim donors, offering <cite id="16">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and serving the <cite id="17">fuqara and masakin</cite> categories.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be strengthened by <cite id="18">clarifying the specific zakat allocation policy</cite> and eligible use categories for donors.

credibility.explanation: Donors can rely on the organization's <cite id="1">57-year history</cite> and its <cite id="12">93.4% independent board</cite>. Financial transparency is supported by <cite id="5">publicly available Form 990 filings</cite>.
credibility.improvement: Credibility could be enhanced by <cite id="15">expanding the board size</cite> beyond the current minimal membership and publishing audited financial statements.

impact.explanation: Operations are highly efficient with a <cite id="6">100.0% program ratio</cite> and <cite id="11">23.6 months of working capital</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact scoring would improve by <cite id="13">publishing consistent beneficiary counts</cite> and seeking external evaluations of educational outcomes.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Financial efficiency verified; outcome data limited

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service provider; not a primary grantmaker

rich_narrative.headline: The Muslim Community Center Incorporate provides comprehensive religious, educational, and social services to the community with a strong commitment to financial efficiency.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value long-term Islamic institutional stability and want to support a comprehensive community hub with high financial efficiency.
donor_motivations: Want to support established Muslim community infrastructure
Prioritize high program-to-expense ratios in their giving
Value multi-service centers that combine education and religion
Seek to fulfill zakat through a trusted local institution
giving_considerations: Gifts support a large, asset-rich institution rather than a lean startup
Impact is measured through community presence rather than RCT data
Focus is primarily on the Chicago metropolitan area
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-rigor academic impact evaluations or those focused on international humanitarian relief.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects high financial efficiency but a lack of external evaluations or tracked outcome metrics.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The organization creates impact by providing essential religious and social services that foster community cohesion and Islamic education.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the $8.6M in annual expenses translates into measurable improvements in community well-being.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: The organization's 17.8% growth rate and expanding service list suggest a high capacity to absorb new funding for infrastructure.

peer_comparison.differentiator: MCC Chicago maintains a <cite id="6">100.0% program ratio</cite>, significantly higher than the <cite id="19">peer median of 89.6%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization directs a <cite id="6">program expense ratio of 93.4%</cite> toward its core services, ensuring donor funds are utilized for community impact.
MCC Chicago maintains <cite id="11">23.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a significant buffer for long-term operational sustainability.
The center operates with high efficiency, requiring only <cite id="7">$0.03 in expenses for every dollar raised</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: MCC Chicago's financial health is characterized by a rare combination of high growth and high efficiency. The organization achieved a <cite id="10">3-year revenue CAGR of 17.8%</cite>, growing from $7.1M in 2021 to nearly $10M in 2023. This growth has been managed while keeping <cite id="12">independent board members at 93.4%</cite>, ensuring strong oversight. Furthermore, the organization's <cite id="9">$19.3M asset base</cite> provides the infrastructure necessary to support its diverse programs, from the <cite id="4">full-time school</cite> to specialized <cite id="3">funeral and marriage rites</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: The Muslim Community Center Incorporate (MCC Chicago) is a long-standing institution that serves as a cornerstone for religious, educational, and social life in the Chicago area. <cite id="1">founded in 1969</cite>, the organization has evolved into a multi-faceted community hub providing <cite id="2">daily and Friday congregational prayers</cite>, <cite id="3">funeral and marriage services</cite>, and a <cite id="4">full-time school</cite>. Financially, the organization demonstrates significant scale, reporting <cite id="5">$9,945,910 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year. A defining characteristic of MCC Chicago is its commitment to direct service delivery, maintaining a <cite id="6">program expense ratio of 93.4%</cite> according to recent financial filings. This efficiency is further bolstered by a lean fundraising model, where the organization spends only <cite id="7">$0.03 to raise every $1</cite>. Beyond its religious functions, the center manages <cite id="8">library services and hall reservations</cite>, facilitating a broad range of community gatherings. The organization's sustainability is supported by a strong balance sheet, ending 2023 with <cite id="9">$19,394,203 in total assets</cite> and a robust <cite id="10">3-year revenue CAGR of 17.8%</cite>, indicating steady growth and community trust.
